html:
7.24.17  6:59 pm   Do you think that somebody's who has never picked up an instrument and knows nothing about music theory can appreciate music or have the same love of music as a musician?

     I feel like the answer should be yes... But, at the same time, I'm not so sure... There's definitely something about creating/playing music that may give you a special connection. I'm not a "professional" musician by any stretch of the imagination (i just play with friends, occasionally do some recordings for fun).. but all my friends play music. so much of my free time is spent playing/writing music and it's just such a huge part of my life.
original_html:

html: 7.24.17  6:38 pm   Hi, I want to learn to improvise on the piano. I have about 10 years of piano lessons behind me, but I still can't seem to "just make stuff up" I don't understand how some people can just listen to a tune and improvise something that sounds incredible off of it. I know some music theory so I can do very simple harmony beneath a melody that I've heard, but I don't know how to make it sound good or jazzy. When I try to mess around on the piano I always revert back to trying to follow the rules I've been taught but failing to turn it into an effective song. Do you have any ideas or tips for how I might be able to improvise more effectively and learn how to harmonize in ways that sound good and rich to me and others?
